title: Tillis challenger Cunningham raises nearly $4.4M in first quarter
summary:
Democrat Cal Cunningham, who is seeking to unseat North Carolina GOP Sen. Thom Tillis in November, will report raising nearly $4.4 million during the first quarter of 2020, his campaign told CQ Roll Call.
The race is among the nation’s most competitive Senate contests and is drawing significant expenditures from super PACs and other outside groups.
Through Dec. 31, the most Tillis raised for his reelection effort in a single quarter was $1.9 million.
Overall, he has raised nearly $6.9 million between Jan. 1, 2019, and Feb. 12, 2020, FEC records show.
Tillis has also entered into joint fundraising ventures with other vulnerable GOP incumbents, including Colorado Sen. Cory Gardner.

title: Trump Reprises State of the Union Message in North Carolina
summary:
CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Three days after his State of the Union address, President Trump traveled on Friday to North Carolina to drive home one of the speech’s major themes.
“This is a blue-collar boom,” Mr. Trump said, repeating what he told Congress was responsible for “the great American comeback.” He added, “Boom!”The president’s visit to a Charlotte community college gave him a chance to celebrate a 3.6 percent unemployment rate, the latest jobs numbers, which showed that employers added 255,000 jobs in January, and the 2017 tax bill.
All of those issues are key components of what is expected to be the centerpiece of his re-election campaign: the economy.
He boasted about his poll numbers, the 2016 election, his relationship with China, soldiers coming home and criminal justice overhaul.
He derided Democrats over their trade policies and the chaos during the Iowa caucuses on Monday, and he dismissed the “failed impeachment hoax.”

title: 2020 Guide To Meteor Showers, Supermoons In Charlotte
summary:
To start your resolution off right, note that astronomers are buzzing about the Quadrantid meteor shower that peaks Jan. 3-4.
April 22-23, Lyrid meteor shower peak: This meteor shower running April 16-25 isn't the best of the year, but with warmer weather settling in, it's worth a look.
May 6-7, Eta Aquarid meteor shower peak: This above-average, long-running meteor shower from April 19 to May 28 produces up to 30 meteors an hour at its peak.
Nov. 4-5, Taurid meteor shower peak: The Taurids are active for longer than any other meteor shower of the year, running annually from Sept. 7 to Dec. 10.
Dec. 21-22, Ursid meteor shower: This minor meteor shower runs Dec. 17-25 and produces around five to 10 meteors at the peak.

title: Annual Toll Rate Increase for Charlotte Expressways Coming Jan. 1
summary:
CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The North Carolina Department of Transportation says annual toll rate increases for the Triangle and Monroe Expressways in Charlotte will take effect on Wednesday, January 1, 2020.
For bill-by-mail customers, the cost will go up 16 cents to $5.33.
For customers traveling on the Monroe Expressway between the western entrance on U.S. 74 to the eastern exit on U.S. 74, the cost will increase six cents to $2.60.
The N.C. Turnpike Authority reportedly adopted the schedules of incremental annual toll rate increases for each expressway based on the financing requirements for each project.
Drivers can get a free NC Quick Pass transponder that can be used on all toll facilities in North Carolina and saves travelers 35 percent compared to the Bill by Mail rate.

Followers of the Old Farmer's Almanac in the Northeast are bracing for a "Wet & Wild" winter 2019-20, whereas devotees of the Farmers' Almanac are preparing for a "Frosty, Wet & White" winter season.

But it also means that services such as the U.S. Post Office, banks and public schools will not open on the day.
During the debate of that bill, it was proposed that Washington's Birthday be renamed Presidents Day to celebrate the birthdays of both Washington on Feb. 22 and President Abraham Lincoln's birthday on Feb. 12.

Nearly 30 candidates are scrambling for the seats now held by three Republicans.
The departing members are Reps. Mark Walker, George Holding and Mark Meadows.
Holding and Walker are stepping aside because redistricting in the fall shifted their Republican districts so that they would favor Democrats.
Meadows isn't seeking reelection because he could soon be working for President Donald Trump.

As the legend goes, if the prognosticating groundhog Punxsutawney Phil sees his shadow, winter will stick around for six more weeks; if not, spring is just around the corner.
Before there was a Groundhog Day, there was Candlemas, an early Christian holiday in which candles were blessed and distributed by local clergy.

title: Snow next week in North Carolina – what’s the deal?
summary:
RALEIGH, N.C. (WNCN) — There’s just about a month left in winter and we still have not had any measurable snow in central North Carolina.
A handful of computer models showed North and South Carolina getting hit with the first snow of the season later next week.
The usual weather pattern that brings snow to North Carolina is one where a cold front moves through bringing a blast of colder air.
That cold air needs reinforcements in the form of high pressure continuing to feed cold air in from the north.
These same computer models have already given central North Carolina several snow storms this winter, just like in the summer these same computer models have the Carolinas getting hit with numerous hurricanes.

CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) — A federal judge has refused to dismiss conspiracy and bribery counts against a North Carolina insurance magnate and two associates.
U.S. District Judge Max Cogburn rejected the motions filed by Greg E. Lindberg, John Gray and John Palermo in an order released Friday.
The indictment charges the three with trying to bribe state Insurance Commissioner Mike Causey with up to $2 million in campaign funds in return for his removing or replacing the regulator that examined insurance business.
Prosecutors have said Causey helped them uncover the scheme.
The decision means the case against the three is set to go to trial in February.

title: 'New' Old Farmer's Almanac Winter 2020 Predictions For NC
summary:
The Old Farmer's Almanac, which is not to be confused with its rival forecast predictor, Farmer's Almanac, recently released its prediction for 2020.
You can look forward to a mild, wet winter in North Carolina this year – that is if you trust the forecasting abilities at The Old Farmer's Almanac.
Followers of the Old Farmer's Almanac in the Northeast are bracing for a "Wet & Wild" winter 2019-20, whereas devotees of the Farmers' Almanac are preparing for a "Frosty, Wet & White" winter season.
According to The Old Farmer's Almanac, the 2020 winter in the U.S. will be remembered for storms that bring an unrelenting amount of rain, sleet and snow — including seven "big snowstorms" across the country.
The Old Farmer's Almanac is North America's oldest continuously published periodical, according to their website.

CHARLOTTE, NC — Shooting stars are zipping across the skies most of the month, with the first of two October meteor showers — the Draconids — peaking Tuesday evening.
The Orionid meteor shower is also active right now, but won't peak until Oct. 22-23.
Though the Draconid meteor shower peaks Tuesday, meteors may also be visible on Monday and Wednesday night, according to Earthsky.org.
Related: 2019 Guide To Meteor Showers, Lunar Eclipse, Supermoons In NCIn some outburst years, the shower produces thousands of meteors an hour.
Orionid Meteor Shower Going On Now, TooThe Orionid meteor shower, which is going on right now, continues through Nov. 7, peaking overnight Oct. 22-23.

summary:
byMissions of Mercy organizers expect to treat as many as 1,500 adults at a free dental clinic Oct. 18-19 at Bojangles' Coliseum.
Organizers with the nonprofit hope to treat as many as 1,500 adults in the Charlotte region who lack access to dental care with North Carolina’s largest free dental clinic Oct. 18-19 at Bojangles’ Coliseum.
“It’s important for volunteers to sign up today so we can make the most of every clinic hour.”The Charlotte clinic is named after the late Dr. Kenneth Owen, a Charlotte orthodontist who founded and served as director of the clinic, officially known as the NCMOM-Kenneth D. Owen-Charlotte Clinic.
The clinic is a part of the North Carolina Dental Society’s outreach program but is entirely funded and organized locally by volunteers.
The Charlotte clinics are the largest and most comprehensive held in North Carolina, performing dental work valued at $4.6 million for nearly 7,300 patients.

title: Charlotte Black Restaurant Week set for Oct. 21-27
summary:
Charlotte Black Restaurant Week (CBRW) returns for its third year Oct. 21-27, with nearly 20 restaurants and eateries expected to participate in one of the city’s burgeoning annual culinary events.
This year, event organizers — Black Business Owners of Charlotte — are doubling down on the need to host their signature event.
Since 2010, 23 Black-owned Charlotte restaurants have closed their doors within the first three years of operations, according to Cathay Dawkins, Black Business Owners of Charlotte’s founder and CEO.
“BBOC has built strong relationships with restaurant owners and staff, and we see CBRW as one of many ways that we can tangibly invest back into local Black-owned restaurants and keep their doors swinging open,” he said.
Patrons will find both newer and more well-established eateries on the roster.

title: Near All-Time Record High for October Possible This Week
summary:
RALEIGH, N.C. -- The hottest temperature ever recorded during the month of October in the Triangle was 98 on October 6, 1954.
High temperatures later this week will get very close to those all-time records for October especially in the Triangle.
High temperatures are forecast to reach the mid to upper 90s for Wednesday and Thursday.
Even if we do not quite make it to the all-time record high for October, it does appear likely that we will set new record highs for the date on Wednesday and Thursday.
A cold front will move through the state at the end of the week finally bringing more fall-like temperatures for the weekend.

title: Real ID North Carolina: What You Need To Get Your New ID
summary:
CHARLOTTE, NC — North Carolina authorities are urging residents to get to a driver license office soon to get a Real ID compliant driver's license or other approved ID ahead of next year's deadline.
While the October 2020 deadline is when the Real ID Act will officially be enforced, it is not the last day you may get the new ID, says the North Carolina Department of Transportation.
As of the end of summer 2019, 1.3 million North Carolina residents are Real ID compliant.
One document with your full name and social security number confirming your social security number, such as an original (not a copy) of your social security card or a W-2 form with your full name and social security number.
For details about what documents you'll need to apply for pre-verification, go to the North Carolina Real ID website.

title: Drought Conditions Spread across North Carolina
summary:
The latest drought monitor released Thursday shows much of North Carolina from the mountains to near Raleigh is either under abnormally dry or moderate drought conditions.

That is keeping eastern North Carolina out of drought conditions for now.

Only very small rain chances are in the forecast across the state for the rest of the month.

Civetta Italian Kitchen + Bar opened earlier this year in Ballantyne’s StoneCrest at Piper Glen among a sea of chains—Firebirds, Chipotle, Jersey Mike’s, Chick-fil-A—in the old Smoke Modern Barbecue space.

title: Tillis challenger Cunningham raises nearly $4.4M in first quarter

Democrat Cal Cunningham, who is seeking to unseat North Carolina GOP Sen. Thom Tillis in November, will report raising nearly $4.4 million during the first quarter of 2020, his campaign told CQ Roll Call.
The race is among the nation’s most competitive Senate contests and is drawing significant expenditures from super PACs and other outside groups.
Through Dec. 31, the most Tillis raised for his reelection effort in a single quarter was $1.9 million.
Overall, he has raised nearly $6.9 million between Jan. 1, 2019, and Feb. 12, 2020, FEC records show.
Tillis has also entered into joint fundraising ventures with other vulnerable GOP incumbents, including Colorado Sen. Cory Gardner.

title: DXC Technology Prices Senior Notes Offering
summary:
DXC Technology Company (NYSE: DXC) ("DXC") today announced the pricing of an offering of (i) $500 million aggregate principal amount of its 4.000% Senior Notes due 2023 (the "2023 Notes"), priced at 99.884% of the aggregate principal amount, and (ii) $500 million aggregate principal amount of its 4.125% Senior Notes due 2025 (together with the 2023 Notes, the "Notes"), priced at 99.791% of the aggregate principal amount.
Lloyds Securities Inc. and Mizuho Securities USA LLC also served as joint bookrunners for the Notes.
The issuance of the Notes is expected to close on or about April 21, 2020, subject to customary closing conditions.
A registration statement, including a prospectus, relating to the offering of the Notes has been filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (the "SEC") and is effective.
ABOUT DXC TECHNOLOGYDXC Technology (NYSE: DXC) helps global companies run their mission critical systems and operations while modernizing IT, optimizing data architectures, and ensuring security and scalability across public, private and hybrid clouds.

title: Earnhardt Jr., Edwards And Burton Among New Nominees For Hall Of Fame
summary:
Dale Earnhardt Jr., Jeff Burton, and Carl Edwards were among the new nominees for NASCAR’s next Hall of Fame class announced Tuesday under a revamped voting protocol.
The new process starting this year splits the nominees into three ballots; Modern candidates, Pioneer candidates and Landmark candidates.
Burton, Earnhardt, Edwards, Jake Elder, and Banjo Matthews are all first-time nominees for the Hall of Fame.
Edwards won 28 Cup races and twice failed to win the Cup title in the season finale.
Series officials realistically are targeting the Coca-Cola 600 on May 24 for the return of racing, but NASCAR had no announcement on when Hall of Fame voting will be conducted.

title: Winter Solstice, Ursid Meteors 2019: How To See In Charlotte
summary:
For anyone stretching their winter solstice revelry into the evening hours, here's a bonus: The Ursid meteor shower peaks overnight Saturday and Sunday.
The winter solstice occurs at the exact moment the North Pole tilts the farthest away from the sun.
The winter solstice, the oldest-known winter celebration, is derived from the Latin word "solstitium," which means "sun standing still."
Several of the rituals associated with Christmas — dinner feasts, gift-giving and decorative wreaths, for example — are rooted in pagan winter solstice rituals.
It may surprise you that the earliest sunsets and latest sunrises don't occur on the winter solstice.

title: Extremism, Anti-Semitism In North Carolina: 65 Incidents In 2019
summary:
CHARLOTTE — In 2019, there were 65 incidents of extremism and anti-Semitism in North Carolina, according to the Anti-Defamation League.
The figure for 2019 increased from the 50 incidents reported in our state during 2018.
The occurrences in North Carolina were among the 4,015 examples of extremist and anti-Semitic incidents that happened nationwide in 2019.
The figure reported for 2019 is up almost 32 percent from the 3,052 incidents reported in 2018, according to the ADL.
The Anti-Defamation League's interactive map includes information on incidents involving anti-Semitism, white supremacist propaganda, white supremacist events, extremist-police shootouts, terrorist plots and attacks and extremist murders.

A low pressure system lifting north from the Gulf of Mexico will spread rain back into the area Friday.
With temperatures remaining above freezing through the day, we'll just look for a cold rain Friday region wide.

title: Charlotte is a shining destination in the Carolinas
summary:
It’s been called the top travel destination in the Carolinas and one of the fastest growing cities in the country.
Four new hotels opened since January of this year, and in 2018, nine new hotels sprang up.
In 2018, the Charlotte region hosted approximately 29.2 million visitors, an increase of 900,000 from 2017, according to research firm Longwoods International.
Charlotte will get a chance to shine in the spotlight as host city of the 2020 Republican National Convention.

title: Community Matters Cafe Hosts Christmas at the Cafe Event
summary:
CHARLOTTE, N.C. — On Saturday, December 14, the Community Matters Cafe will host a Christmas at the Cafe event to raise money for those in need during the holidays.
A gingerbread house silent auction will also take place during the event.
Christmas at the Cafe will take place from 2:30 to 4:30 p.m. on Saturday at 821 West 1st Street.
The Community Matters Cafe is an extension program of the Charlotte Rescue Mission, which is a non-profit orginization that provides free, Christian-based residential recovery services to men and women struggling with substance abuse and homelessness.

title: Panthers owner David Tepper willing to pay up to bring the MLS to Charlotte, report says
summary:
CHARLOTTE, NORTH CAROLINA - DECEMBER 01: Carolina Panthers owner David Tepper looks on before their game against the Washington Redskins at Bank of America Stadium on December 01, 2019 in Charlotte, North Carolina.
Carolina Panthers owner and hedge-fund manager David Tepper is pushing for a Major League Soccer expansion team in Charlotte and is prepared to pay up to seal the deal, according to a report from Charlotte Business Journal.
CBJ reported that the MLS could make a decision on the league's next expansion team by the end of 2019.
Charlotte already has quite the roster of professional sports teams, making it an attractive choice for an MLS expansion club.
Sacramento became the most recent city awarded an MLS expansion club in October.

title: CMPD Identifies Man Intentionally Hit and Killed in SW Charlotte
summary:
CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Detectives with the Charlotte-Mecklenburg Police Department are still looking for the suspect responsible for a vehicular homicide in Southwest Charlotte Friday afternoon.
Police say Robert Hopkins was intentionally hit by a vehicle in Southwest CharlotteHopkins died from injuriesCMPD looking for the driver responsibleThe incident happened around 3 p.m. near South Tryon Street and Ayrsley Town Boulevard.
Police say the victim, identified as Robert Michael Hopkins, was intentionally struck by a vehicle in the area and transported by Medic to Atrium Health CMC with life threatening injuries.
Shortly after arriving at the hospital, police say Hopkins, 56, was pronounced dead.
&amp;nbsp;No arrests have been made at this time, and police have not released any suspect information.

title: NCDOT: Heavy Traffic Expected Through the Holiday Season
summary:
NORTH CAROLINA — The North Carolina Department of Transportation is warning travelers to plan ahead this holiday season due to high volumes of traffic expected on state roadways.
Those suspensions will begin on Friday, December 20 and last through Thursday, January 2 to accommodate travelers for Christmas and New Years.
The NCDOT says travelers should plan their trips in advance due to the high volumes of traffic expected this holiday season.
To avoid some of the traffic, the NCDOT advises drivers to leave early and travel during non-peak hours.
Officials say the weekends before Christmas and New Years and Christmas Eve will be the most congested.
